{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} "'''Along the Navajo Trail'''" is a [[country music|country]]/[[popular music|pop]] song, written by Dick Charles (pseudonym for [[Richard Charles Krieg]]), [[Larry Markes]], and [[Eddie DeLange]] in [[1945 in music|1945]].
It was the [[title song]] of the 1945 [[Roy Rogers]] film ''[[Along the Navajo Trail (film)|Along the Navajo Trail]]''. It was also used in the 1945 film ''[[Don't Fence Me In (film)|Don't Fence Me In]]'' when it was sung by Roy Rogers and the [[Sons of the Pioneers]].{{cite web|title=Internet Movie Database|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0037656/soundtrack?ref_=tt_trv_snd|website=imdb.com|accessdate=September 9, 2017}}
Members of the [[Western Writers of America]] chose it as one of the Top 100 Western songs of all time.{{Cite web|title=The Top 100 Western Songs |author=Western Writers of America |year=2010 |authorlink=Western Writers of America |publisher=American Cowboy |url=http://www.americancowboy.com/culture/top-100-western-songs |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RjFQXqGy?url=http://www.americancowboy.com/culture/top-100-western-songs |archivedate=10 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}
Charted versions in 1945 were by [[Bing Crosby]] and [[The Andrews Sisters]] (recorded June 29, 1945){{cite web|title=A Bing Crosby Discography|url=http://www.bingmagazine.co.uk/bingmagazine/crosby1bDecca.html|website=BING magazine|publisher=International Club Crosby|accessdate=September 9, 2017}} (No. 2); [[Gene Krupa]] (vocal by [[Buddy Stewart]]) (No. 7); and [[Dinah Shore]] (No. 7).{{cite book|last1=Whitburn|first1=Joel|title=Joel Whitburn's Pop Memories 1890-1954|date=1986|publisher=Record Research Inc|location=Wisconsin, USA|isbn=0-89820-083-0|page=470}} The song has been recorded by many other artists, including: *[[Duane Eddy]] - included in his album ''[[Especially for You (Duane Eddy album)|Especially for You]]'' (1959). *[[Fats Domino]] (1963) http://www.fatsonline.nl/domino.html 2.2014 *[[The Honey Dreamers]] *[[Steve Kuhn]] and [[Toshiko Akiyoshi]] *[[Frankie Laine]] - for his album ''Hell Bent for Leather!'' (1961).{{cite web|title=Discogs.com|url=https://www.discogs.com/Frankie-Laine-Hell-Bent-For-Leather/master/267263|website=Discogs.com|accessdate=September 9, 2017}} *[[Riders in the Sky (band)|Riders in the Sky]] *[[Roy Rogers]] (1945).{{cite web|title=45worlds.com|url=http://www.45worlds.com/78rpm/record/201730|website=45worlds.com|accessdate=September 9, 2017}} *[[Bob Wills]] and the Texas Playboys *[[Sam Cooke]] - included in his album ''[[Encore (Sam Cooke album)|Encore]]'' (1958). *[[Hot Club of Cowtown]], 2011 == References == {{Bing Crosby}} {{The Andrews Sisters}} {{Duane Eddy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Along The Navajo Trail (Song)}} [[Category:Western music (North America)]] [[Category:Songs about places]] [[Category:Songs written by Dick Charles]] [[Category:Songs written by Larry Markes]] [[Category:1945 songs]] [[Category:Songs with lyrics by Eddie DeLange]] {{pop-song-stub}}

revision.comment: Not quite sure why trapdoor is relevant, but here's the German word for it.
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Spantekow Angstloch.jpg|thumb|upright|An ''angstloch'' at [[Spantekow Fortress]]]] [[File:Angstloch.jpg|thumb|upright|left|An ''angstloch'' at [[Wildenburg Castle (Eifel)|Wildenburg Castle]]]]
An '''''angstloch''''' (apparently "fear hole", but more probably from the [[Latin|Lat.]] ''angustus'' "narrow" and German ''Loch'' "hole") was a small hole in the floor of [[medieval]] [[castle]]s and [[fortress]]es that led to a cellar or basement room below. The term is German and has no English equivalent, although a door, where there is one, to such a hole is called a [[trapdoor]] (German: ''Falltür'').
An ''angstloch'' is usually located above the basement of a fighting tower or ''[[bergfried]]''. The description of these basement rooms as "[[dungeon]]s" stems from the romanticised castle studies of the 19th century. There is no evidence to indicate that prisoners were really lowered through the ''angstloch'' into the dungeon using a rope or [[rope ladder]] as these 19th century accounts suggest. Archaeological finds, by contrast, indicate the use of these basement spaces as store rooms. For example, piles of stones have been found in such rooms that suggest they were used as a store for projectiles to be used in time of [[siege]].
== Literature == * Günther Binding: ''Architektonische Formenlehre.'' Wissenschaftliche Buchgesellschaft, Darmstadt, 1987, {{ISBN|3534078616}}, pp. 191, 223 ({{Google books|qQ5NAAAAYAAJ||page=223}}). * Alois Brandstetter: ''Die Burg.'' Residenz Verlag, 1986, {{ISBN|3701704309}}, p. 293 ({{Google books|5B0lAAAAMAAJ||page=293}}). * Otto Piper: ''Abriss der Burgenkunde.'' Göschen Collection, Volume 119. G. J. Göschen, 1900, pp. 47ff. ({{Google books|eKkVAAAAYAAJ||page=47}}). * Otto Piper: ''Burgenkunde.'' Weidlich, 1967, p. 664 ({{Google books|tEM3AQAAIAAJ||page=664}}).

'''(Secretary)'''{{cite web|url=http://www.jazzinbelgium.com/venue/id=611?lang=nl|title=Antwerpse Jazz Club|access-date=13 September 2016|publisher=Lundis d'Hortense}} | coords =
* '''Clubhouse:''' {{Coord|51|13|17.8|N|4|23|58.9|E}} * '''Secretary:''' {{Coord|51|13|10.7|N|4|28|50.9|E}} | region = [[Flanders]], Belgium | headquarters = Second floor of Café Den Bengel, [[Grote Markt (Antwerp)|Grote Markt]] 5, 2000 [[Antwerp]], Belgium. * '''Currently:''' {{Official URL}} {{URL|http://www.AntwerpseJazzClub.com|AntwerpseJazzClub.com}} {{Nl icon}} * '''Previously (archived):''' {{URL|https://web.archive.org/web/20101219173015/http://www.AntwerpseJazzClub.be/|AntwerpseJazzClub.be}} {{Nl icon}} | purpose = ''"The study and propaganda of the jazz-music, as it was created and played by the [[African Americans|Afro-Americans]] of the United States, by means of the exemplified listening of music- and image recordings, through lectures at third parties about the nature and movements of jazz and, if feasible the organizing of concerts with American jazz musicians."'' | key_people =
* Marc Vanistendael; * Josée Lissens; and * Language professor Piet Van De Craen }} The '''Antwerp Jazz Club''' ({{lang-nl|Antwerpse Jazzclub}}, abbreviated '''AJC''') is an association in [[Antwerp]], Belgium, founded in 1938{{cite web|url=http://www.lionelhampton.nl/antwerpsejazzclub.html|title=Antwerpse Jazz Club|author=Hans Bebop Bonefaas|date=16 April 2014|access-date=12 September 2016}} by Hans Philippi,{{cite web|url=http://www.antwerpsejazzclub.com/index.php?page=club|title=De Club|publisher=Antwerpse Jazz Club|access-date=12 September 2016}} which delivers weekly lectures about and presentations of [[jazz]] music,{{cite magazine|url=https://issuu.com/webredactie/docs/dp_60936_verenigingengids_district_antwerpen201021/9|page=16|title=Verenigingen. Gids. District Antwerpen|date=2010–2011|first1=Femke|last1=Syvertsen|first2=Kelly|last2=Stark|first3=Ann|last3=Melis|publisher=Jos Bergmans|id=Wettelijk Depotnummer D/2009/0306/320|location=[[Antwerp]]|department=District Antwerpen (Stad Antwerpen)}} at no cost, open to the public at large. Its sessions are held in Dutch. Other than these sessions, the club organizes concerts, including helping to organize [[blues]] concerts; and has aided in the screenings of jazz documentaries. Its Tuesday-sessions are held mostly by a member, and if not by another amateur of jazz, and are often illustrated by DVD-recordings. They are held every Tuesday night from 20PM until 22PM, but not during the [[Christmas]] period, nor the month of July. On request, the association also organises events about jazz for interested associations. The [[jazz club]] is a member of: * "De Stedelijke Culturele Raad van Antwerpen" (an advisory body which features civil participation in culture-related policy of the city of Antwerp{{cite web|url=https://www.antwerpen.be/nl/info/stedelijke-cultuurraad|title=Stedelijke cultuurraad|publisher=Stad Antwerpen [City of Antwerp]|date=18 September 2014|access-date=12 September 2016}}); * [[Hot Club de France]]; and * Centre for Black Music Research, [[Chicago]], United States. The now obsolete Dutch-language website Gratisinantwerpen.be, which was supported by the city of Antwerp and listed free events in Antwerp (the website also had a less complete English version at Antwerpforfree.be), used to advertise the weekly Tuesday-sessions of the ''AJC''.{{cite web|url=http://gratisinantwerpen.be/ |date=14 February 2014 |archive-date=2014-02-14 |access-date=13 September 2016 |title=ALLES WAT GRATIS IS DEZE WEEK / ALL THE FREE EVENTS THIS WEEK |publisher=Guerilla vzw |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214164758/http://gratisinantwerpen.be/ |df= }} ''AJC'' is a subscriber to a number of jazz magazines, from the United States and from several European countries, which can be consulted in its clubhouse. == History == [[File:Guy Van Looy presenting his multimedia blues presentation entitled 'Portraits in Blues 57; Het SPIVEY PLATENLABEL' (meaning The SPIVEY RECORD LABEL) at the Antwerp Jazz Club (AJC) (13 September 2016).jpg|thumb|Guy Van Looy presenting his multimedia blues presentation entitled "Portraits in Blues 57: The SPIVEY RECORD LABEL" at the Antwerp Jazz Club (AJC) on 13 September 2016. Marc Vanistendael can be seen in the far left of the picture.]] In 1938, the club started as gatherings to listen to commented jazz music, which remains the main activity of the club today (info {{as of|lc=y|2016}}). Since 1950, the club also started organizing concerts. Among the famous jazz musicians who have performed in Antwerp in the 1950s and 1960s, due to the ''AJC'', are: [[Willie "The Lion" Smith]], [[Big Bill Broonzy]], [[Earl Hines]], [[Memphis Slim]], [[Buck Clayton]], [[Bill Coleman]], [[Buddy Tate]], [[Ben Webster]], [[Illinois Jacquet]], [[Ray Bryant]] and [[Guy Lafitte]].{{cite magazine|url=https://issuu.com/jazzmozaiek/docs/jm0801_vol_web/21|editor1=Luc De Baefs|editor2=Bernard Lefèvre|publisher=Muziekmozaïek vzw|year=2008|issue=1|page=21|magazine=Muziekmozaïek|first=Bernard|last=Lefèvre|title=Antwerpse Jazzclub 70! "Doordringen tot de essentie van de jazz"}} On 28 April 1963 the ''AJC'' celebrated its [[silver jubilee]]. The "Archive of Fons Van Cleempoel" (an archive spanning the years 1968—1988, created by "{{ill|Amsab - Institute for Social History|nl|Amsab-Instituut voor Sociale Geschiedenis}}", in partnership with the "European Holocaust Research Infrastructure (EHRI)" and the "National Archives of Belgium"){{cite web|url=https://portal.ehri-project.eu/units/be-002143-be_amsab_isg_505|title=Archief van Fons Van Cleempoel|id=BE / Amsab-ISG / 505|access-date=13 September 2016|publisher=European Holocaust Research Infrastructure (EHRI)}} entails some documents from the ''AJC''.{{cite report|url=ftp://digital.amsab.be/finding_aids/finding_aid_BE_AMSAB_505.pdf|id=S/1988/505, S/2000/527, S/2011/507|title=Plaatsingslijst van het archief van Fons Van Cleempoel (1968-1988)|publisher=Amsab - Instituut voor Sociale Geschiedenis}} On the club's seventy-year jubilee, the club honoured its own history by means of showing its own concert recordings, lengthy documentation and imagery during its Tuesday-sessions. On 18 August 2016, the Antwerp cinema "Cinema Zuid" (the new name of the Antwerp "Filmmuseum" since 12 September 2009, after it had moved to the Antwerp district "[[Zuid, Antwerp|South]]" in 2004 under the [[Museum of Modern Art, Antwerp|Museum of Contemporary Art in Antwerp]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemazuid.be/nl/contacteer|title=Over Cinema Zuid|access-date=13 September 2016|website=Cinema Zuid}} in collaboration with the ''AJC'', organized a screening of two documentaries about the Belgian jazz musician and [[Conducting|conductor]] [[Stan Brenders]] and about the jazz guitarist [[Django Reinhardt]] respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemazuid.be/nl/film/manneken-swing-swing-guitar-genius-django-reinhardt|title=MANNEKEN SWING + SWING GUITAR: THE GENIUS OF DJANGO REINHARDT|publisher=Cinema Zuid|access-date=13 September 2016}} == Location == [[File:Protected_monuments_in_Antwerp_'Ambachtshuis_de_Mouwe'_(alternative_names;_'de_gulde_Mouwe'_or_'het_Cuypershuys'_in_the_center,_and_at_its_left;_'Burgerhuis_Witten_Engel',_and_at_its_right;_'Huis_Spaengien'_(13_September_2016,_19;45PM).jpg|thumb|The clubhouse of ''AJC'' is located on the second floor (where windows can be seen opened) of the building in the centre (Ambachtshuis de Mouwe), a protected monument. Picture taken on 13 September 2016, fifteen minutes before the 8PM Tuesday-session of the jazz club.]] Since 8 November 1994, ''AJC'' holds its sessions in a bar called "Den Bengel" in Antwerp.{{cite web|url=http://www.denbengel.be/Jazz_New.html|website=Cafe Den Bengel|title=Verenigingen gevestigd in "Den Bengel". ANTWERPSE JAZZCLUB|date=27 February 2016|access-date=12 September 2016}} More precisely, the clubhouse of ''AJC'' is housed in the same building as that bar (which occupies the ground floor), yet on the second floor. The building is actually an old [[guildhall|guild house]] ({{lang-nl|ambachtshuis}}) called "Ambachtshuis de Mouwe" (alternative names: "de gulde Mouwe" or "het Cuypershuys"), which is registered and protected as a monument since 2 September 1976 into the Flemish inventary of [[immovable property]], part of the [[heritage registers in Belgium]].{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4034|title=Ambachtshuis de Mouwe. inventaris bouwkundig erfgoed \ bouwkundig relict|id=4034|publisher=Onroerend Erfgoed (Flemish Government)|access-date=14 September 2016}} The building's ground floor is dated 1579, its [[gable]] is dated 1628. The building was originally the "house" of the [[craft]] of [[cooper (profession)|cooperage]] ({{lang-nl|kamer van het Kuipersambacht}}). The architectural style of the building is [[renaissance architecture]], it was designed by Léonard Blomme, and restaured in 1907. The top of the building is crowned with a triangular [[pediment]] which holds a gilded statue of [[Saint Matthias]], the [[patron saint]] of the coopers. The building is part of the square [[Grote Markt (Antwerp)|Grote Markt]]. When facing its [[facade|façade]], one finds the building [https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4033 Burgerhuis Witten Engel] {{Nl icon}} at its left and the building [https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4035 Huis Spaengien] {{Nl icon}} at its right, which are also protected monuments.{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4033|title=Burgerhuis Witten Engel. inventaris bouwkundig erfgoed \ bouwkundig relict|id=4033|publisher=Onroerend Erfgoed (Flemish Government)|access-date=14 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/4035|title=Huis Spaengien. inventaris bouwkundig erfgoed \ bouwkundig relict|id=4035|publisher=Onroerend Erfgoed (Flemish Government)|access-date=14 September 2016}} == Notable persons == One of its board members is Piet Van De Craen,{{cite web|title=antwerpse jazz club |website=willy's blog |access-date=13 September 2016 |archive-url=https://blog.seniorennet.be/cowboy/tvblog.php?startaantal=5 |url=https://blog.seniorennet.be/cowboy/tvblog.php?startaantal=5 |archive-date=24 August 2016 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} a full-time{{cite web|url=http://research.vub.ac.be/food-history/piet-van-de-craen|publisher=[[Vrije Universiteit Brussel]]|access-date=13 September 2016|series=Research > Social & Cultural Food Studies|title=Piet Van De Craen}} language professor of Dutch Linguistics and of General Linguistics at the [[Vrije Universiteit Brussel]],{{cite news|url=http://www.vrijzinnigwestvlaanderen.be/deze-maand/evenementdetail/904/-/jazz-koksijde3-0-met-piet-van-de-craen|title=Jazz@Koksijde3.0 met Piet van de Craen|publisher=Vrijzinnig West-Vlaanderen|first=Marc|last=Van Muylen|location=VOC de koepel, Westhoek, Houtsaegerlaan 21, 8670 Koksijde, Belgium|date=4 October 2015}} who has been called a major force behind the jazz club. For the occasion of the seventy-year jubilee of the ''AJC'' in 2008, Piet Van De Craen published a monograph about [[Duke Ellington]] (the first ever publication about him in Dutch) which features a concise biography and discography, looks at Ellington as a pianist/composer and at Ellington's co-operation with [[Billy Strayhorn]] and "The Ellingtonians" before and after 1943. In the same year, Piet Van De Craen also criticized the lack of references to jazz history in the United States: {{quote|text=The United States doesn't learn anything from the history. Everytime there is a new president, one starts all over again. It is a country where connections are not made. And then it happens that, for example with [[Oscar Peterson]], recently died, the press doesn't make any reference to [[Art Tatum]], just as if Peterson arose out of nowhere ... that kind of profundity is lacking.}} === Presidents === ==== Hans Philippi ==== Hans Philippi (born 17 December 1905) founded both the ''AJC'', as well as the ''Hot Club Basel'', a jazz club in [[Basel]], Switzerland. He was an early advocate of the recognition of jazz as an art. He had his own radio series, held jazz music presentations by means of playing sound records throughout Switzerland and was acquainted with jazz musicians such as [[Louis Armstrong]] and jazz experts such as [[Hugues Panassié]] and [[Charles Delaunay]].{{cite report|url=http://www.jazzdocumentation.ch/mario/philippi/1einleitung.pdf|date=24 March 2006|title=Jazz in der Schweiz 1924-1976. Zeitdokumente des Hans Philippi aus Basel. Das Verzeichnis|chapter=Einleitung|author=Mario Schneeberger|access-date=12 September 2016|website=JAZZdocumentation.ch}} The Swiss jazz musician Mario Schneeberger compiled a list of notable documents regarding Hans Philippi, from the memorial albums of Philippi, after an acquaintance of Schneeberger had told him that they were about to be put up as garbage disposal following a [[house clearance]] in February 2004. In this archive by Mario Schneeberger, it is noted that Hans Philippi was president of the ''AJC'' in 1938, as from a booklet of that year produced by the ''AJC'' called "Jazz-Leven".{{cite report|url=http://www.jazzdocumentation.ch/mario/philippi/3orte.pdf|date=24 March 2006|title=Jazz in der Schweiz 1924-1976. Zeitdokumente des Hans Philippi aus Basel. Das Verzeichnis|chapter=Orte|author=Mario Schneeberger|access-date=12 September 2016|website=JAZZdocumentation.ch}} ==== Louis Vaes and François Vaes ==== The activities of the club were coordinated by Louis Vaes (1920—1998) from 1946 until 1998. Later, his brother François Vaes (born 1939), nicknamed "Sus",{{cite web|url=http://www.muziekmozaiek.be/index.php?action=nieuwsdetail&nieuws=2336&titel=Antwerpse+Jazz+Club+in+rouw&select_onderdeel=4090|title=Antwerpse Jazz Club in rouw|series=JAZZ. Jazzweblog|publisher=Muziekmozaïek|date=12 August 2012|access-date=12 September 2016}} became president of the club, until he died after a "short disease" on 9 August 2012. François Vaes advocated for youths to appreciate the roots of jazz, as opposed to being seemingly merely interested in new or trendy jazz music. ==See also== * [[Jazz in Belgium]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official|http://www.antwerpsejazzclub.com/}} {{nl icon}} * {{cite web|url= http://www.muziekmozaiek.be/demo_muzmoz/files/File/download/JM_edities/JM801/JM81_AJC.pdf |title=Article in the Flemish jazz magazine "Jazzmozaïek" about the celebration of the 70-year existence of the jazz club }} {{small|(129 KB)}} {{Nl icon}} [[Category:Jazz clubs in Belgium]] [[Category:Antwerp]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:Jazz organizations]] [[Category:Belgian jazz]] [[Category:Jazz culture]]

{{no footnotes|date=February 2017}} An '''artist development deal''' is often the first of a [[recording artist]]'s contracts with a major [[record label]]. In lieu of high [[royalties]] or other desirable rights, the label will promise to develop the skills and [[public profile]] of the artist. These types of deals are sometimes most helpful to the artist, but the label often takes control of the artist's management and publishing rights. Historically, such deals have been abused by both record labels and managers.
==References== * "[[Divided Soul: The Life of Marvin Gaye]]" - [[David Ritz]] 1984 * "Dreamgirl: My Life as a Supreme" - [[Mary Wilson (singer)|Mary Wilson]]

[[File:Portrait of Bonaventura Peeters the Elder.jpg|thumb|240px|Portrait of Bonaventure Peeters, by [[Wenceslas Hollar]]]] '''Bonaventura Peeters (I)''' or '''Bonaventura Peeters the Elder''' (23 July 1614 – 25 July 1652) was a Flemish [[painter]], draughtsman and etcher. He became one of the leading [[marine art]]ists in the Low Countries in the first half of the 17th century with his depictions of marine battles, storms at sea, shipwrecks and views of ships in rivers and harbours.<ref name="vlieghe">Hans Vlieghe (1998). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=AS_NXFoY0M4C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Flemish Art and Architecture, 1585-1700]''. Pelican History of Art. New Haven: Yale University Press. {{ISBN|0-300-07038-1}}</ref> <ref name=rkd>[https://rkd.nl/explore/artists/62354 Bonaventura Peeters (I)] at the [[Netherlands Institute for Art History]] {{link language|nl|Middle Dutch}}</ref>
==Life== Peeters was born in [[Antwerp]] as the son of Cornelis Peeters and Catharina van Eelen.<ref name=bran>F. J. Van den Branden, 'Geschiedenis der Antwerpsche schilderschool', 2 vols (Antwerp, 1883), pp. 1046–1050 {{link language|nl|Middle Dutch}}</ref> He was baptised in the church of St. Walpurgis in Antwerp on 23 July 1614.<ref name=jan>[http://johnnyvanhaeften.com/media/blog/PEETERS%20Bonaventura%20VP4742%20shipping%20in%20choppy%20seas%20(2).pdf Bonaventura Peeters the Elder, ''Shipping in choppy Seas off Willemstad''] at Johnny van Haeften</ref> He was a brother of the seascape painters [[Jan Peeters I|Jan the Elder]], [[Gillis Peeters the Elder|Gillis the Elder]] and [[Catharina Peeters]].<ref>[https://rkd.nl/explore/artists/373225 Catharina Peeters] at the Netherlands Institute for Art History {{link language|nl|Middle Dutch}}</ref> [[File:Bonaventura Peeters (I) - Seascape with Sailors Sheltering from a Rainstorm.jpg|left|thumb|270px|Seascape with Sailors Sheltering from a Rainstorm]]
Nothing is known about his early training although it is possible that [[Andries van Eertvelt]], a specialist of stormy sea paintings, was his master. Bonaventura became a master in Antwerp's [[Guild of Saint Luke]] in 1634.<ref name=rkd/> On 5 July 1638 he received a commission of the pensionary of Antwerp to produce maps of the [[Battle of Kallo|Siege of Kallo]] and Verrebroek which had occurred only one month earlier. He was able to deliver the maps half a month later. This earned him a subsequent commission from the pensionary for a large painting of the Siege of Kallo, which he completed in collaboration with his brother Gillis.<ref name=bran/> He became one of the few marine specialists active in the Southern Netherlands during the mid-17th century.<ref name=jan/>
Initially he shared a studio in Antwerp with his older brother Gillis. However, he moved in 1641 to [[Hoboken (Antwerp)]] where he lived in a spacious residence and worked in a studio with his pupils Catharina and Jan Peeters (I).<ref name=rkd/><ref name=mar>Margarita Russell. "Peeters, Bonaventura, I." Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online. Oxford University Press. Web. 18 Oct. 2014</ref> He was the teacher of his siblings Catharina and Jan Peeters (I).<ref name=rkd/>
Peeters never married and died in Hoboken, aged 38 after suffering from ill health the last years of his life.<ref name=moust>[http://www.jeanmoust.com/index.cfm?page=artist-index&cat=4149&subcat=9207&aid=734403&artist=Peeters,%20Bonaventura%20I,%20Tangier About Bonaventura Peeters I] at Jean Moust</ref>
==Work== [[File:Bonaventura Peeters (I) - Icebear Hunt on the Coast of Norway (?).jpg|thumb|320px|Polar Bear Hunt on the Coast of Norway]]
Bonaventura's marine paintings comprise the whole range of battle scenes, storms, shipwrecks, views of ships in rivers, coastal waters and harbours, night scenes etc. His earliest marine paintings are panoramic views. His intimate and accurate knowledge of ships may hint at an early life spent at sea. He paid particular attention to the detailed depiction of clouds and waves.<ref name=moust/>
His earlier works show a similarity to the tonal phase of Dutch [[landscape painting]]. Later paintings reflect the stronger colours of Italianate [[classicism]].<ref name="vlieghe" /> This shift follows the general change in artistic style at the time.<ref name=mar/> Dramatic shipwrecks with dark billowy clouds form a significant part of his oeuvre, as do serene ports and "[[portrait]]s" of ships.<ref name="vlieghe" /><ref name=mar/><ref>[http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/houb005groo01_01/houb005groo01_01_0187.htm Bonaventuur Peeters biography] in: [[Arnold Houbraken]], ''De groote schouburgh der Nederlantsche konstschilders en schilderessen'', 1718 {{link language|nl|Middle Dutch}}</ref> [[Image:Bonaventura Peeters-Port in Orient mg 3001.jpg|thumb|left|280px|A port in the Orient]]
Many of Peeters' paintings depict actual locations along the [[North Sea]] and the river [[Scheldt]] and these subjects form the bulk of his artistic production. He may have even travelled along the coast of [[Scandinavia]] as is shown by his views of the port of [[Arkhangelsk|Archangel]] in Northern Russia one of which offers a scene of reindeers or elks pulling sledges. His other views of Scandinavian ports and scenes support the view that he may have travelled there.<ref name=moust/> Bonaventura Peeters the Elder repeatedly returned to the portrayal of seaports with shipping in the foreground. Peeters the Elder developed something of a speciality in the portrayal of seaports with shipping in the foreground. His first such view dates to 1634, the year in which he became a master in the Antwerp guild. It depicts [[:File:Bonaventura Peeters (I) - The 'Hercules' and 'Eenhorn' off the port of Hoorn.jpg|''The 'Hercules' and 'Eenhorn' off the port of Hoorn'']] (1634, [[National Maritime Museum]], London). Peeters’ oeuvre includes a number of smaller examples of this type, including three views of Willemstad, taken from different angles, and a view of Brouwershaven, in Rotterdam.<ref name=jan/>
His many views of far-away [[Mediterranean]] and [[Middle Eastern]] ports reflect a growing taste for the exotic and are probably completely imaginary or derived from prints, including those by his younger brother Jan who had travelled in Southern Europe.<ref name="vlieghe" /><ref name=mar/><ref name=moust/> This tradition developed simultaneously in [[Flemish Baroque painting]] and in [[Dutch Golden Age painting]], with many artists, including Peeters, working in both Antwerp and in the [[Dutch Republic]].<ref name="vlieghe" /> For his views of Brazil Bonaventura may have relied on descriptions or depictions by his brother Gillis, who had travelled to South America.<ref name=moust/> [[File:Bonaventura Peeters (I) - The 'Hercules' and 'Eenhorn' off the port of Hoorn.jpg|thumb|320px|The 'Hercules' and 'Eenhorn' off the port of Hoorn]]
Bonaventura Peeters is known also for his drawings and engravings with maritime subjects. One of them entitled ''Ships in a storm'' ([[Plantin-Moretus Museum]] in Antwerp) has a poem by him on its back in which he compares the dangers at sea with the dangers that man has to face over a lifetime.<ref name=moust/> His drawings, as well as those of his family members Jan Peeters I and Bonaventura Peeters II, were used in the preparation of the [[Laurens van der Hem|Blaeu's Atlas Maior of the whole world]] (Atlas Blaeu-Van der Hem).<ref>[http://www.blaeuvanderhem.com/default.aspx?pageid=5 Atlas Blaeu-Van der Hem] at Brill</ref>
Bonaventura collaborated with other family members and artists in Antwerp. For instance, he collaborated with his brother Gillis on a painting of the ''[[Battle of Kallo]]''. As he was a gifted [[staffage]] painter he was asked by other painters to paint the figures in their compositions. His collaboration with father and son [[Pieter Neeffs I|Pieter Neeffs the Elder]] and [[Pieter Neeffs II|the Younger]], painters of church interiors, is documented in the signed examples in the [[National Gallery]] in London and the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]] in Vienna.<ref name=moust/>
==References== [[File:Bonaventura Peeters (I) - Arrival of the Boat.jpg|thumb|320px|Arrival of the Boat]]<references /> ==External links== *{{Commons-inline|Category:Bonaventura Peeters (I)|Bonaventura Peeters the Elder}}
{{Authority control}} {{use dmy dates|date=May 2011}}

page.title: Book trade in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} '''Book trade in the United Kingdom''' has its roots as far back as the 14th century, however the emergence of [[E-commerce|internet]] [[booksellers]] such as [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] partnered with the introduction of the [[e-Book]] has drastically altered the scope of the industry. Book retailers such as the [[Borders Group]] have failed to adjust to these changes, thus there has been a steep decline in the number of operating traditional and independent bookshops. However, still heavily influential on the trade globally, British publishers such as [[Penguin Books]] and [[Pearson PLC|Pearson]] remain dominant players within the industry and continue to publish titles gloablly.
[[File:Charles Dickens - Project Gutenberg eText 13103.jpg|thumb|Charles Dickens: [http://www.gutenberg.org Project Gutenberg]]]
==History==
By the 14th century a commercial book trade had been established in the UK, and before printing was introduced to Europe by Johannes Gutenberg in 1439 the trade consisted of scribes who wrote manuscripts.<ref>Feather, John, ''A History of British Publishing'', 2nd ed (GB:Routledge Ltd, 2005)P.9</ref> By the early 15th century the majority of those engaged in these activities were situated in London and belonged to a trade guild called the Company of [[Stationers]].<ref>Feather, John, ''A History of British Publishing'', 2nd ed (GB:Routledge Ltd, 2005)p.23</ref> By the 16th century publishers and printers controlled the book trade and introduced a commercial aspect, relying for much of their income on the sales of popular religious books, almanacs, prognostications and similar literature.<ref>Feather, John, ''A History of British Publishing'', 2nd ed (GB:Routledge Ltd, 2005) p.26</ref> By the 20th century, as literacy became increasingly universal within society and disposable income increased, publishers were faced with new opportunities. In 1900 the [[Net Book Agreement]] was introduced to ‘help to maintain a chain of stock holding bookshops while giving the publishers sufficient confidence to publish new titles’<ref>Feather, John, ''A History of British Publishing'', 2nd ed (GB:Routledge Ltd, 2005) P150</ref>
The introduction and demise of the [[Net Book Agreement]] heavily impacted the [[publishing industry]]. First established in 1900, the Act involved an agreement between booksellers and publishers to fix the price of books in order to "help maintain a chain of stock holding bookshops while giving the publishers sufficient confidence to publish new titles"<ref>Feather, John, ''A History of British Publishing'', 2nd ed (GB:Routledge Ltd, 2005)p.150</ref>
==Recent developments== The structure of the industry within the UK has altered significantly over the last few decades, which now establishes itself as part of wider industry globally dominated by international giants such a [[Pearson PLC|Pearson]] (UK), [[Muse Corporation]] (United States), and [[Hachette (publisher)|Hachette]] (France). The gap between small independent booksellers and giant chain sellers has vastly increased, leading to the dissolution of many medium-sized companies; "Overall the number of significant companies has dropped by ten percent in the last decade".<ref>Richardson, Paul; Taylor, Graham, ''A Guide to the UK Publishing Industry'', (London: The Publishers Association, 2008) p15</ref> Technology has extensively affected developments within the publishing industry. Due to having one of the highest levels of internet connectivity in Europe, the industry in the UK experiences the prevalent threat and the vast opportunity of revolutionary technological advances such as the [[e-book]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]]; almost all book publishers in the UK now utilize the standard book number.<ref>Richardson, Paul; Taylor, Graham, ''A Guide to the UK Publishing Industry'', (London: The Publishers Association, 2008)p.52</ref>
Bookshops have begun to decline over the years, with just over 73 closures in 2013 alone, the UK lost 7% of its remaining Independent book stores.<ref>Flood, Alison, ''Decline in Independent Bookshops continues with 73 closures in 2012'', The Guardian (https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/feb/22/independent-bookshops-73-closures-2012) [accessed 03/12/2014]</ref> The number of independent book shops has now fallen below 1,000 (2014) whilst even bigger booksellers such as [[Borders]] went into liquidation.<ref>Spector, Mike,''Borders forced to liquidate, Close all stores'', The Wall Street Journal (http://online.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303661904576454353768550280) [accessed 03/12/2014]</ref>
In 2013 the publishing contributed to the UK creative economy with 231,000 jobs that had an almost equal split between men and women.<ref>[http://www.thecreativeindustries.co.uk/industries/publishing/publishing-facts-and-figures], The Creative Industries website, accessed 10 December 2015</ref>
From 2014, brick and mortar shops have been performing better, seeing a light at the end of the Recession period and the boom of the Kindle. Looking at the data provided, Richard Mollet, chief executive of The Publishers Association, explains that "those who ever tried to maintain that this was a binary choice have been shown to have been posing the question in the wrong way. It is not a question of either physical or digital winning out, but rather of the sector coalescing around a balanced marketplace where all formats have place. While publishing has been efficient and effective in its adaptation, the underlying driver of the evolution is of course the reader. What the 21st-century consumer desires above all is choice. As long as publishers can give readers the option of paper or screen, the market will - and is - taking care of itself. The ebook is no more a challenge to the lifespan of paper than television is to the theatre".<ref>{{Cite book|title = PA statistics yearbook 2014|last = Clee|first = Nicholas|publisher = Publishers Association|year = 2014|isbn = 978-0853863694|location =|pages =}}</ref>
UK publishers of online, publicly accessible [[open access]] books include [[Open Book Publishers]], [[Ubiquity Press]], and [[UCL Press]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://re.ukri.org/blog/helen-snaith/open-access-and-monographs/ |title=Open access and monographs |date=27 July 2018 |work= Re.ukri.org |publisher=[[Research England]] }}</ref>

{{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Bran Nue Dae | image = Bran Nue Dae poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Rachel Perkins]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Robyn Kershaw]] * Graeme Isaac}} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * [[Reg Cribb]] * Rachel Perkins}} | based on = {{based on|''[[Bran Nue Dae]]''|[[Jimmy Chi]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Rocky McKenzie]] * [[Jessica Mauboy]] * [[Ernie Dingo]] * [[Missy Higgins]] * [[Geoffrey Rush]]}} | music = Cezary Skubiszewski | cinematography = [[Andrew Lesnie]] | editing = Rochelle Oshlack | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Film Victoria]] * Mayfan * Omnilab Media * [[Robyn Kershaw|Robyn Kershaw Productions]] * [[Screen Australia]]}} | distributor = [[Roadshow Entertainment|Roadshow Films]]
[[Freestyle Releasing]]http://freestylereleasing.com/bran-nue-dae/ | released = {{Film date|df=y|2009|08|09|[[Melbourne International Film Festival|Melbourne]]|2010|01|14}} | runtime = 85 minutes | country = Australia | language = English | budget = {{A$|7 million}}Production information [http://www.screendaily.com/production/asia-pacific/australia/bran-nue-dae/5000646.article Bran Nue Dae], ''[[ScreenDaily.com]]''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. | gross = {{A$|$7.5 million}}[http://if.com.au/2010/03/01/article/YAVPPVCSKF.html Box Office: Bran Nue Dae breaks $7m] {{Webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6YpFAYYs6?url=http://if.com.au/2010/03/01/article/YAVPPVCSKF.html# |date=27 May 2015 }} – By Brendan Swift – if.com – Retrieved 8 January 2012. }} '''''Bran Nue Dae''''' is a 2009 Australian [[Musical film|musical]] [[comedy-drama]] film directed by [[Rachel Perkins]] and written by Perkins and [[Reg Cribb]]. A feature [[film adaptation]] of the 1990 stage musical ''[[Bran Nue Dae]]'' by [[Jimmy Chi]], the film tells the story of the coming of age of an [[Aboriginal Australian]] teenager on a road trip in the late 1960s. ==Plot== In [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]] in 1969, Willie Johnson ([[Rocky McKenzie]]) is having trouble wooing his girl Rosie ([[Jessica Mauboy]]), who ends up with a bandleader named Lester ([[Dan Sultan]]). His mother Theresa ([[Ningali Lawford]]) sends him back to [[boarding school]] in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] to continue his education for the priesthood. One night, he and several others steal food from the college kitchen but are caught. Willie admits to being the thief, but runs away before he can be punished. He spends the night on the streets of Perth before meeting up with 'Uncle' Tadpole ([[Ernie Dingo]]), who offers to help him get home. They go to [[Fremantle]] where Tadpole allows himself to be run over by a [[Volkswagen Type 2|Kombi van]], hoping that the two hippies inside will help him. Not realising how far it will be to Broome, the hippies, 'Slippery' the German ([[Tom Budge]]) and Annie ([[Missy Higgins]]), his girlfriend, agree to drive them. Father Benedictus ([[Geoffrey Rush]]), head of the College, has seen Willie's potential and determines to locate him; through Tadpole's homeless friends, he learns that Willie is heading to Broome. The travellers drive north, stopping at a [[Roadhouse (facility)|roadhouse]] where Willie meets the tarty 'Roadhouse Betty' ([[Magda Szubanski]]). Tadpole steals some food, a bottle of wine, and an audio tape, nearly causing them to get shot by Betty, but they manage to escape. Slippery becomes disillusioned, and leaves Willie and Tadpole behind in the middle of nowhere; Tadpole curses the hippies by [[Kurdaitcha|pointing a bone]], and the van promptly breaks down. Willie then gets a ride with a passing truck carrying the members of a football team. They end up in Port Hedland where he meets flirty Roxanne ([[Deborah Mailman]]), who takes him to the 'condom tree' and offers to 'show him a good time', but her boyfriend turns up and a fight ensues. Willie is rescued by Tadpole, who says that all young men end up there at some point. The next morning, they are driving along a desert road when a hung-over Roxanne emerges from the back seat, startling everyone. While smoking some pot, they are discovered by police and arrested, despite Annie's attempts at stopping the police from arresting them. At the police station, Slippery reveals that his real name is Wolfgang Benedictus. The police then put them in a jail cell for a night. They are released next morning, and drive on to Broome, where they go to the bar where Rosie is performing. Willie tries to win her back, but ends up in a fight with Lester, only to be disrupted by a church [[Temperance movement|temperance march]], which invites everyone to the beach to testify. Willie tells Rosie he loves her, and they kiss. At the beach, Willie's mother reveals that she had a son to another man, who turns out to be Father Benedictus. Wolfgang is their son. Tadpole is spotted by Willie's mother, and she tells Willie that he is Tadpole's son. ==Cast== * [[Rocky McKenzie]] as William "Willie" Johnson, the film's [[protagonist]]; a rebellious teenage boy who escapes the Catholic Mission in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] to return to his home in [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]]. * [[Jessica Mauboy]] as Rosie, an aspiring singer and the love of Willie's life. Mauboy, who was runner-up in the fourth season of ''[[Australian Idol]]'', makes her acting debut.[http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,25867340-5017007,00.html Singer Jessica Mauboy stars in WA film] ''[[Perth Now]]''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. * [[Ernie Dingo]] as Stephen "Uncle Tadpole" Johnson, a drunk who accompanies Willie on his adventure. Dingo played the role of Tadpole in the original production of the stage play ''Bran Nue Dae'' in 1989.[http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/wa/5789334/bran-nue-dae-dawns-on-film/ Bran Nue Dae dawns on film] ''[[Yahoo! News]]''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. * [[Missy Higgins]] as Annie, Slippery's spiritual girlfriend who is travelling with him to Perth. This is Higgins' acting debut.[http://artists.letssingit.com/missy-higgins-qjmmt/news/ New Film – Bran Nue Dae] ''Lets Sing It''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. * [[Geoffrey Rush]] as Father Benedictus, the film's [[antagonist]]; as a strict German priest who runs the Catholic Mission in Perth training young men to become priests, he pursues Willie who ran away from the school. The role was offered to Rush by director Perkins.[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24564737-16947,00.html Geoffrey Rush to star in film of Aboriginal musical Bran Nue Dae] ''[[The Australian]]''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. * [[Tom Budge]] as Slippery, a German hippie tourist travelling with his girlfriend Annie in a [[Volkswagen Type 2|Kombi van]]. * [[Deborah Mailman]] as Roxanne * [[Ningali Lawford]] as Theresa, Willie's mother. Ningali is one of the cast members from the original 1989 stage production of ''Bran Nue Dae''. * [[Stephen "Baamba" Albert]] as Pastor Flaggon. Stephen is also one of the cast members from the original 1989 stage production of ''Bran Nue Dae''. * [[Dan Sultan]] as Lester, the local band leader who finds himself in love with Rosie. * [[Magda Szubanski]] as Roadhouse Betty, the frisky owner of a Roadhouse.[http://www.filmink.com.au/filmbiz/blog/bran-nue-last-day/ BRAN NUE LAST DAY] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929133209/http://www.filmink.com.au/filmbiz/blog/bran-nue-last-day/ |date=29 September 2009 }} ''Film Ink'' ==Release== ''Bran Nue Dae'' [[premiere]]d at the [[Melbourne International Film Festival]] on its closing night on 8 August 2009.[http://www.screendaily.com/balibo-and-bran-nue-dae-to-bookend-melbourne-film-festival/5001394.article ''Balibo'' and ''Bran Nue Dae'' to bookend Melbourne Film Festival] ''[[ScreenDaily.com]]''. Retrieved 25 September 2009. The film made its international debut at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] at the [[Scotiabank Theatre Toronto|Scotiabank Theatre]] on 12 September 2009.[http://www.screenwest.com.au/go/news/a-bran-nue-dae-at-toronto-international-film-festival A ''Bran Nue Dae'' at Toronto International Film Festival] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930214954/http://www.screenwest.com.au/go/news/a-bran-nue-dae-at-toronto-international-film-festival |date=30 September 2009 }} ''ScreenWest''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. The film will be among the lineup of out-of-competition films to be screened at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in 2010.[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2009/12/sundance-2010s-outofcompetition-lineup-announced-next-spotlight-launched.html Sundance Film Festival 2010's out-of-competition lineup announced, NEXT (<=>), Spotlight launched] ''[[Latimes.com]]''. Retrieved 7 December 2009. The film made its official theatrical premiere at the Sun Pictures theatre in [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]], [[Western Australia]] on 8 December 2009 where the stars of the film walked a "red dirt" carpet.Australian premiere. [http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,26450883-5005380,00.html Red carpet for Broome premiere of Bran Nue Dae] ''[[PerthNow]]''. Retrieved 7 December 2009. In the lead up to the premiere on the day, stars of the film Mauboy, Sultan, Higgins, and Dingo put on a public performance with the [[Kuckles]] band in Broome's Chinatown. ===Box office=== The film was theatrically released in Australia on 14 January 2010[http://thecia.com.au/reviews/b/bran-nue-dae.shtml ''Bran Nue Dae''] at Cinematic Intelligence Agency and had an opening weekend rank of No. 6, averaging $6,977 at 231 screens for a gross of $1.6 million,[http://moviemarshal.com.au/ausweek21-01-10.html Aus Top 20 (14–17 January 2010)] – Published By Paul Boschen – Retrieved 8 January 2012 $3.7 million in its first two weeks{{cite web | url = http://www.asiapacificarts.usc.edu/article@apa?starting_up_a_bran_nue_dae_interview_with_director_rachel_perkins_15634.aspx | title = Starting up a Bran Nue Dae: interview with director Rachel Perkins | publisher = Asia Pacific Arts | date = 9 November 2010}}- Retrieved 8 January 2012. and eventually grossing more than $7.5 million. The film "... has since become one of the Top 50 Australian films of all time at the local box office." ===Critical reception=== The film received generally mixed reviews. Review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 56% of critics have given the film a positive review, based on 61 reviews with an average score of 5.9/10. The website's critical consensus is: "It's original and high-spirited, but ''Bran Nue Dae'' is also uneven and sometimes overly kitschy."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/bran-nue-day/ |title=Bran Nue Dae (2010) |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=16 March 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 54 out of 100, based on 5022 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/bran-nue-dae |title=Bran Nue Dae Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=16 March 2018}} Dennis Harvey of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said "It retains that dated once-almost-hip look – like [[Up with People]]", but it contained "blandly stereotypical characters in a trite road-trip narrative" and in regards to younger audiences, claimed "There's scant real dancing, mostly forgettable, showtune-type songs and no ethnic authenticity."{{cite news|last=Harvey|first=Dennis|url=https://variety.com/2009/film/markets-festivals/bran-nue-dae-1200476072/|title=Bran Nue Dae|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=17 September 2009|accessdate=16 March 2018}} [[Craig Mathieson]] of [[SBS Television|SBS Films]] commented that "''Bran Nue Dae'' has a daffy, garish energy that's reflected in brisk pacing and up-tempo tunes". On director Perkins, he stated "Visually, Perkins is not a natural fit for this material", comparing it to her 1998 feature ''[[Radiance (1998 film)|Radiance]]'', but "here she enthusiastically takes to the moments of farce and productions numbers." Mathieson added that the "frames feel cluttered, with an occasional echo of the amped-up musical melodrama" but concluded approvingly that ''Bran Nue Dae'' was similar to the 1982 Australian musical film ''[[Starstruck (1982 film)|Starstruck]]'' in that it "carries the day with energy and self-belief."{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/movies/review/bran-nue-dae-review |title=Bran Nue Dae Review |work=[[SBS Television|SBS Films]] |publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] |date=11 August 2009|accessdate=16 March 2018|last=Mathieson|first=Craig}} ''[[The Age]]''{{'}}s Philippa Hawker praised the cast, stating Dingo was "terrific as Uncle Tadpole", for Rush who "brings an idiosyncratic physical energy and an extravagant German accent to the role" and newcomer [[Jessica Mauboy]] brought "sweetness and confidence to the role of Rosie".{{cite news|last=Hawker|first=Philippa|title=Indigenous film's world premiere introduces some Bran Nue stars|url=https://www.theage.com.au/articles/2009/08/07/1249350685435.html|work=[[The Age]]|date=8 August 2009|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=16 March 2018}} ===Accolades=== The following is a list of awards that ''Bran Nue Dae'' or the cast have been nominated for or won: ;Wins * [[Melbourne International Film Festival]] awards[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/21/2662695.htm ''Bran Nue Dae'', ''Balibo'' take MIFF top honours] ''[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]''. Retrieved 25 September 2009. ** Audience award for Best Feature ;Nominations * [[2009 Toronto International Film Festival]][http://www.tiff.net/filmsandschedules/films/brannuedae Toronto International Film Festival: ''Bran Nue Dae''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090920231445/http://www.tiff.net/filmsandschedules/films/brannuedae |date=20 September 2009 }} ''tiff.net''. Retrieved 26 September 2009. ** People's Choice Award ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Bran Nue Dae-Official Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | artist = Various Artists | cover = | caption = | alt = | released = {{Start date|df=y|2010|1|15}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Rhythm & Blues]]

{{Other uses|Bulla (disambiguation){{!}}Bulla}} [[File:Roman boy wearing bulla.jpg|thumb|Detail from a [[relief]] showing a Roman boy wearing a ''bulla'']] [[File:Etruscan - Bulla with Daedalus and Icarus - Walters 57371 - Side A.jpg|thumb|Etruscan bulla picturing [[Icarus]]]]
'''Bulla''', an [[amulet]] worn like a locket, was given to male [[children of Ancient Rome|children]] in [[Ancient Rome]] nine days after birth. Rather similar objects are rare finds from Late Bronze Age Ireland.
==Roman bullae== Roman bullae were enigmatic objects of lead, sometimes covered in gold foil, if the family could afford it. A bulla was worn around the neck as a locket to protect against evil spirits and forces. Bullae were made of differing substances depending upon the wealth of the family.
===Roman boys=== Before the age of manhood, Roman boys wore a bulla, a neckchain and round pouch containing protective amulets (usually [[Fascinum|phallic symbols]]), and the bulla of an upper-class boy would be made of gold.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vroma.org/~bmcmanus/clothing.html |title=Roman Clothing |at=Part I |publisher=Vroma.org |access-date=2012-11-07 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Other materials included leather and cloth.
A freeborn Roman boy wore a bulla until he came of age as a [[Roman citizen]]. Before he put on his ''[[toga]] virilis'' ("toga of manhood") he placed his boyhood bulla in the care of his parental household deities ([[Lares]].<ref>Clarke, John R., ''The Houses of Roman Italy, 100 BC-AD 250. Ritual, Space and Decoration,'' illustrated, University Presses of California, Columbia and Princeton, 1992, pp. 9-10; citing [[Propertius]], 4.1.13 & [[Persius]], ''The Satires'', 5.30-1.</ref>. Some modern sources interpret [[Macrobius]]'s single reference to an amulet worn by a triumphal general during his procession as evidence that the childhood bulla was also a standard item of [[Roman triumph|triumphal regalia]].<ref>[[Mary Beard (classicist)|Beard, Mary]]: ''[[The Roman Triumph]]'', The Belknap Press of [[Harvard University Press]], Cambridge, Mass., and London, England, 2007, pp. 229-230, 375-376, note 29; citing see also Macrobius, 3. 6. 9. {{ISBN|978-0-674-02613-1}}</ref>
===Roman girls=== {{main|Lunula (amulet)}} A girl child did not wear a bulla per-se,<ref>{{cite book |first1=J.L. |last1=Sebesta |first2=L. |last2=Bonfante |title=The World of Roman Costume |publisher=The University of Wisconsin Press |year=2001 |page=47 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> but another kind of amulet, called a [[Lunula (amulet)|lunula]], until the eve of her [[marriage]], when it was removed along with her childhood [[toy]]s and other things. She would then stop wearing child's clothes and start wearing women's [[Roman Dress]].
==Bronze Age Ireland== A small number of bullae have been found in Ireland; they are called “bullae” based on their resemblance to the Roman form.<ref group=lower-alpha>Other than superficial resemblance, Irish and Roman bullae have no known connection.</ref> The Irish bullae so-far found were made of base metal<ref group=lower-alpha>Irish bullae are usually made of lead, but also tin. Bullae made of clay are rare.</ref> – sometimes clay – covered with a folded over piece of gold foil. The Irish bullae date to the Late Bronze Age, between about 1150 BCE–750 BCE.
They were presumably worn suspended round the neck with a cord running through the hole below the flat top. The body of the bulla has roughly vertical sides before making a semi-circle or inverted pointed arch at the bottom. The gold is incised with geometrical decoration.
Whether they were purely for adornment or had an amuletic or other function is unclear. Despite the small weight of gold used they would have been only available for elite groups.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://finds.org.uk/bronzeage/objects/bullae |title=Bullae |series=Bronze Age objects |publisher=Portable Antiquities Scheme |location=UK |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808090352/http://finds.org.uk/bronzeage/objects/bullae |archive-date=8 August 2013 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museum.ie/en/list/artefacts.aspx?article=d0214472-a18a-4fc4-b0c4-018a181ce345 |title=Bulla |dead-url=yes |date=November 2016 |publisher=National Museum of Ireland |df= |access-date=2013-08-18 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130818160504/http://www.museum.ie/en/list/artefacts.aspx?article=d0214472-a18a-4fc4-b0c4-018a181ce345# |archive-date=2013-08-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Wallace |editor1-first=Patrick F.|editor2-last=O'Floinn |editor2-first=Raghnall |title=Treasures of the National Museum of Ireland |series=Irish Antiquities |volume=3 |page=18 |year=2002 |publisher=Gill & Macmillan |location=Dublin, EI |ISBN=0-7171-2829-6 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Taylor |first=Joan J. |year=1980 |title=Bronze Age Goldwork of the British Isles |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UDI9AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA63 |via=Google Books |pages=65 ff |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
